translated: As It Was Said
The Fours
The Chapter on the Spiritual Life of the Holy Life
The Ending of Defilements

analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā vuttam arahatā iti me suta
translated: This was said by the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha:

original: “Jānatohaṁ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṁ khayaṁ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
analyzed: jānataḥ ha bhikkhave passataḥ āsavānam khayam vadāmi no a jānataḥ no a passataḥ
translated: “Monks, I say that the ending of the effluents is for one who knows & sees, not for one who doesn’t know & doesn’t see.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato, kiṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti?🔽Idaṁ dukkhanti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti. Ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti,🔽bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti, bhikkhave, jānato
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave jānataḥ kim passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti  idam dukkhanti bhikkhave jānataḥ passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha samudayo ti  bhikkhave jānataḥ passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha nirodhaḥ ti bhikkhave jānataḥ
translated: “And what is the knowing, what is the seeing, for the ending of the effluents?🔽“There is the case where one knows & sees form as it actually is. One knows & sees the origination of form as it actually is. One knows & sees the cessation of form as it actually is. One knows & sees the path of practice leading to the cessation of form as it actually is.🔽“One knows & sees feeling as it actually is. One knows & sees the origination of feeling as it actually is. One knows & sees the cessation of feeling as it actually is. One knows & sees the path of practice leading to the cessation of feeling as it actually is.

original: passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti. Ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti, bhikkhave, jānato🔽passato āsavānaṁ khayo hoti.
analyzed: passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ti bhikkhave jānataḥ  passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti
translated: “One knows & sees perception as it actually is. One knows & sees the origination of perception as it actually is. One knows & sees the cessation of perception as it actually is. One knows & sees the path of practice leading to the cessation of perception as it actually is.🔽“One knows & sees the mental formations as they actually are. One knows & sees the origination of the mental formations as it actually is. One knows & sees the cessation of the mental formations as it actually is. One knows & sees the path of practice leading to the cessation of the mental formations as it actually is.🔽“One knows & sees consciousness as it actually is. One knows & sees the origination of consciousness as it actually is. One knows & sees the cessation of consciousness as it actually is. One knows & sees the path of practice leading to the cessation of consciousness as it actually is.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṁ passato āsavānaṁ khayo hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave jānataḥ evam passataḥ āsavānam khayaḥ hoti iti
translated: “This is the knowing, this is the seeing, for the ending of the effluents.”
The Blessed One said this.
And this is how he explained the meaning:
“For the one in training, practicing the path,
following the straight path,

analyzed: kha yasmin paṭhamam ña a ṇa
translated: First knowledge of destruction,
then immediately after, knowledge of non-arising.

analyzed: tatas aññā vimuttassa  vimutti ñāṇam uttama
translated: Then, for one liberated by knowledge,🔽the supreme knowledge of liberation arises.
Knowledge of destruction arises:

analyzed: khīṇā sayojanā iti  na tu eva idam kusītena  bālena am avijānatā
translated: ‘Destroyed are the fetters.’🔽But this is not to be attained by the lazy,
by the foolish, by the undiscerning,🔽Nibbana, the freedom from all fetters,
the supreme state.”

original: Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
analyzed: ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ bhagavatā iti me sutam ti
translated: This, too, was the meaning of what was said by the Lord of the Truth, so I have heard.
The third.
